titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Irvin family papers, 1816-1919, undated 2023ms007
titlestmt.author: Kaylee McMunn

publicationstmt.publisher: University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center

repository.corpname: University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center

did.unittitle: Irvin family papers
did.abstract: The Irvin family papers (dated 1816-1919, undated; 1.4 cubic feet; 2 boxes) primarily comprise correspondence, receipts, ledgers, and indentures that document the Irvin family of Bardstown, Nelson County, Kentucky. Also includes a family diary, materials related to the history of Bardstown, and certificates and orders related to the Kentucky militia.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to researchers by appointment

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged by subject into 4 series.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: The Irvin family of Bardstown, Nelson County, Kentucky, area moved west from Virginia as early as 1818. Bardstown was chartered in 1788 and platted by David and William Bard. The Bard and Irvin family are connected by marriage. Three generations of the Irvin family owned hundreds of acres of Kentucky property plus enslaved people and were likely fairly wealthy farmers and business owners. Tax records from 1837-1839 show Samuel L. Irvin (1789-1842) holding enslaved persons valued at $6250. There is some evidence that at least one of Samuel L. Irvin's sons graduated from Centre College in Danville, Kentucky. The eldest of Samuel's sons, John H. Irvin (1809-1847), became a minister. By the 1880s, David A. Irvin (1824-1888) and Rachel Summers Irvin (1834-1902) owned at least 859 acres of land, with Rachel Irvin owning 20 acres on Buffalo Creek. David A. Irvin served as a as Captain of the Kentucky Militia in 1848, although he did not serve in the Mexican War.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: 2023ms007 : [identification of item], Irvin family papers, 1816-1919, undated, University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Irvin family papers (dated 1816-1919, undated; 1.4 cubic feet; 2 boxes) primarily comprise correspondence, receipts, ledgers, and indentures that document the Irvin family of Bardstown, Nelson County, Kentucky. Also includes a family diary, materials related to the history of Bardstown, and certificates and orders related to the Kentucky militia. The collection series are organized by subject. The correspondence series includes letters between family members, acquaintances, and businesses. The letters primarily focus on business and family affairs. The Financial and legal series includes primarily receipts and ledgers that document the Irvin family finances and business transactions, including references to slaves. The Kentucky militia series includes certificates and orders related to David A. Irvin's service as Captain of the Kentucky Militia in 1848, although he did not serve in the Mexican War. The personal series includes a family diary, notes, maps related to Bardstown and members of the Irvin family.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The physical rights to the materials in this collection are held by the University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Item 1 refers to the care of a slave girl named Milly, dated 1852 February 4.
